title: Simple Sandwich Loaf
description: A classic white sandwich bread that teaches fundamental dough handling. At 65% hydration, this dough is firm enough to knead and shape — the opposite end of the spectrum from focaccia.

steps.instruction: In a large bowl, combine flour, sugar, yeast, and salt. Add the warm water and mix until a shaggy dough forms. Let it rest for 5 minutes.
tips: At 65% hydration, this dough should feel noticeably firmer than a focaccia dough.
The short rest lets the flour absorb the water before you start kneading.

steps.instruction: Turn the dough out onto a clean surface and knead for 8–10 minutes. After 5 minutes, incorporate the softened butter by flattening the dough, spreading the butter on, then folding and kneading until fully absorbed. The dough should become smooth, elastic, and pass the windowpane test.
tips: Windowpane test: pull a small piece of dough thin — if you can stretch it until light passes through without it tearing, the gluten is developed.
Adding butter partway through lets you build gluten first, then enrich.
If the dough tears easily when you stretch it, keep kneading.

steps.instruction: Shape the dough into a ball, place it in a lightly oiled bowl, and cover. Let it rise until doubled in size.
tips: The poke test: press a floured finger into the dough about 1cm deep. If the indent springs back slowly, it's ready. If it springs back fast, it needs more time.
Temperature matters — a warm kitchen (24°C+) speeds fermentation.

steps.instruction: Punch down the dough gently to release large gas bubbles. Turn it out and shape into a log: flatten into a rectangle, fold the top third down and the bottom third up (like a letter), then roll tightly from one short end to the other. Pinch the seam closed.
tips: The 'letter fold then roll' method creates even tension throughout the loaf.
Pinch the seam and ends well — loose seams can open during baking.
Place seam-side down in the pan.

steps.instruction: Place the shaped dough seam-side down in a greased 9x5 inch (23x13cm) loaf pan. Cover and let it proof until the dough crowns about 2.5cm (1 inch) above the rim of the pan.
tips: This usually takes 45 minutes to 1 hour.
While it proofs, preheat your oven to 190°C (375°F).
Don't over-proof — if it rises too much, it may collapse in the oven.

steps.instruction: Bake at 190°C (375°F) until the top is golden brown and the internal temperature reaches 88°C (190°F). The loaf should sound hollow when tapped on the bottom.
tips: If the top browns too quickly, tent with foil for the last 10 minutes.
Remove from the pan immediately and cool on a wire rack.
Resist cutting into it for at least 30 minutes — the crumb is still setting.
